metadata.title: Curve fitting on experimental data of a new hybrid nano-antifreeze viscosity: Presenting new correlations for non-Newtonian nanofluid

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Physica A
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/physa
Curve fitting on experimental data of a new hybrid nano-antifreeze viscosity: Presenting new correlations for non-Newtonian nanofluid Mohammadhossein Irani a, Masoud Afrand b,∗, Babak Mehmandoust a a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Khomeinishahr Branch, Islamic Azad University, Khomeinishahr, Iran b Department of Mechanical Engineering, Najafabad Branch, Islamic Azad University, Najafabad, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
• Preparing homogeneous and stable samples of MWCNTs-Al2O3 hybrid nanofluid. • Measuring viscosity at different shear rates and temperatures by the digital viscometer. • All nanofluid samples were non-Newtonian, following power law model. • Using curve fitting to obtain consistency index and the power law index. • Two-variable correlations were proposed to predict the non-Newtonian behavior.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 October 2018 Received in revised form 18 January 2019 Available online 26 April 2019
Keywords: Curve-fitting Viscosity Hybrid nanofluid Al2O3 nanoparticles MWCNTs Experimental correlation
a b s t r a c t
In this paper, the rheological behavior of a mixture of water and ethylene glycol containing a combination of multi-walled carbon nanotubes and aluminum oxide in a temperature range of 25 to 50 ◦C was investigated experimentally. Homogeneous and stable samples with different concentrations were made by suspending carbon nanotubes and aluminum dioxide in a 50–50 mixture of water and ethylene glycol using a two-step method. The viscosity of nanofluid samples at different shear rates was measured by the DV-I PRIME Brookfield digital viscometer, which uses a rotating cylinder method. The results showed that, despite the Newtonian behavior of the base fluid, all nanofluid samples showed a non-Newtonian behavior. It was also observed that non-Newtonian behavior of nanofluid follows the Power law model. Thus, using the curve fitting, the consistency index and the power law index were obtained. Moreover, mathematical correlations were proposed as a function of temperature and volume fraction for obtaining consistency index and the power-law index. Comparisons showed the accuracy of proposed correlations.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the development of modern technology in various industries, issues like increase of the heat transfer, reduction of the heat transfer time, reduction of the heat exchanger size and increase of the fuel efficiency are necessary. One of the methods for energy saving and efficiency improvement in the industry is cooling. The weak conventional heat transfer is the major barrier to compressing and manufacture of efficient heat transfer devices. These systems are usually among
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: masoud.afrand@pmc.iaun.ac.ir (M. Afrand).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physa.2019.04.073 0378-4371/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
the main concerns of factories and industries. With the advancements of micro industries (nanometer scale), rapid and bulky operations are possible at very high speeds (several GHz). In these industries, the use of high-power and highthermal-load motors has become important such that the use of advanced and optimal cooling systems is inevitable. In most cases, optimization of the existing heat transfer systems is achieved by increasing their rate, which increases the size of these devices. Another solution to overcome this problem is using new coolants. Common fluids used in heat transfer such as water or ethylene glycol have low thermal conductivity. Solid particles have a high thermal conductivity and therefore, by distribution in the base fluid, they can increase thermal conductivity of the fluids [1–3]. Suspensions are formed by dispersing solid particles in pure fluids and provide a novel solution for improvement of the heat transfer in energy carrying fluids. Problems with suspensions with solid particles (metallic, non-metallic, and polymeric) in millimeter and even micrometer scales include particle corrosion, channel blockage, pipe network erosion, reduced transmission momentum, and increased pressure drop. Another problem is instability, as these particles heavily tend to be deposited in the suspension.
To avoid mentioned problems, Choi [4] was the first to use the term ‘‘nanofluid’’ for nanoparticles in liquid suspensions, claiming that such fluids are different to conventional solid/liquid suspensions and macro-fluids both in terms of preparation and in terms of stability and transitional characteristics. The major difference between the nanofluid and conventional suspensions is the very fine size of scattered particles (1 to 100 nm), since many effective forces in the macro dimension lose their effect with smaller particles and give way to intermolecular forces [5–11]. A comparison between suspensions with nanoparticles and suspensions with microparticles shows that suspensions containing nanoparticles are more stable. Moreover, the surface-to-volume ratio is a thousand times larger in these particles than in microparticles and they need less pumping power compared to microparticles suspensions. Their corrosion is also lower compared to microparticles suspensions [12].
Previous literature on nanofluids showed that their properties, such as thermal conductivity and viscosity, are significantly different from conventional fluids. Undoubtedly, thermal conductivity is one of the most-studied properties of nanofluids. A number of studies on the thermal conductivity of nanofluids are summarized in Table 1. These studies reported that thermal conductivity of nanofluids is generally related to the nano-material amount and temperature, and is a function of the type and diameter of nanoparticles.
Viscosity is another parameter that influences the flow and heat transfer of fluids. Viscosity refers to fluid resistance to motion. Viscosity causes a momentum transfer between fluid layers in relative motion. Fluid viscosity is used in calculation of pumping power, mixing, plumbing systems, fluid powdering, fluid storage, fluid injection and transportation. In addition, heat transfer calculations are used to calculate Reynolds and Prandtl numbers. Thus, the viscosity and its changes, Newtonian or non-Newtonian fluids, are of interest for flows. A number of studies on the viscosity of nanofluids have been summarized in Table 2. It has been reported in these studies that many nanofluids exhibited a Newtonian behavior in low nanoparticle concentration, while with the increased concentration of nanoparticles a non-Newtonian behavior has been observed. They also have shown that spherical nanoparticles added to base fluids cause Newtonian behavior, and cylindrical and tetragonal nanoparticles lead to non-Newtonian behavior. In addition, the results showed that nanofluids made of higher viscosity base fluids tend to have a non-Newtonian behavior and nanofluids that are made of lower viscosity base fluids have a Newtonian behavior.
Recently, new nanofluids have been reported made from the dispersion of two different nanomaterials in a common heat transfer fluid. Some researchers studied the viscosity of these nanofluids [34–43]. In fact, when using hybrid nanofluids, it is possible to use the properties of two types of nano-materials, because each of them has special properties.
As reported previously, carbon nanotubes have unique thermal characteristics. Moreover, aluminum oxide is very abundant, reasonably priced and suitable stability. Hence, in this study, with the objective of the creating hybrid nanofluids, a new hybrid nanofluid consisting of aluminum oxide nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes is produced. The base fluid is also a 50–50 volumetric mixture of water and ethylene glycol. Then, the viscosity of the nanofluid samples is measured at different shear rates, temperatures and volumetric concentrations. Also, mathematical relations are proposed to predict the behavior of this hybrid nanofluid.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of the nanofluid
sections.text: In order to perform accurate experiments, the first step is to prepare the nanofluid. Preparation of stable and homogeneous nanofluid is, indeed, one of the main and most important parts of the experiment on nanofluids. The stable and homogeneous nanofluid is a nanofluid which shows no significant deposition if it remains stagnant for a while. There are single-step and two-step method for nanofluid preparation, the latter of which is used in this study. In this method, aluminum oxide powder and multi-walled carbon nanotubes were mixed in a specific amount of ethylene glycol–water base fluid. For the nanoparticles to be well mixed in the base fluid, the mixture was agitated for 45 min with a magnetic agitator. The samples were then subjected to ultrasound (Hielscher, Germany) for 1.5 h with a frequency of 24 kHz and a power of 400 watts, in order to reduce the particles blockage and agglomeration. An image of samples is shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Viscosity and verification measurements
sections.text:
In this study, viscosity measurements were made by the DV-I PRIME Brookfield viscometer instrument, which uses a coaxial cylindrical method. In this instrument, the viscosity is measured and displayed by making a relationship between the angular velocity and torque. These viscometers are also used to measure the viscosity of both Newtonian- and nonNewtonian fluids. During the test, a water bath and a circulator were used to keep the temperature constant in all volume fractions. All measurements were carried out at a temperature range of 25 to 50 ◦C, volume fractions of 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4 and 0.8%, and shear intervals of 2.44S−1 to 78.33S−1.
In order to verify the measurements, experiments were carried out on a base fluid containing 50% water and 50% ethylene glycol. The measurement results were compared with ASHRAE data for this 50–50 mixture. The results are shown in Table 3. As observed, the maximum difference is 2.50%, which is the acceptable value.

sections.heading: 3.1. Rheological behavior of samples
sections.text:
Fig. 2 reveals the shear stress and viscosity of the base fluid in terms of shear rates for various temperatures. As shown in the figure, the shear stress is linearly related to the shear rate at different temperatures, that is, the base fluid has a Newtonian behavior. The constant viscosity at high shear rates also confirms the Newtonian behavior of the base fluid.
Fig. 3 demonstrates the shear stress and viscosity of all nanofluid samples in terms of shear rates at various temperatures. As can be observed, at all volume fractions, shear stress has a relation similar to pseudo plastic behavior with the shear rates. This figure also shows that the viscosity decreases with increasing shear rates; i.e. the behavior of the fluid is shear thinning. It is also observed that as the temperature increases, the viscosity decreases and with an increase in the volume fraction, the apparent viscosity increases.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of temperature on nanofluid viscosity
sections.text:
Fig. 4 is presented to better understand the effect of temperature on nanofluid viscosity. In this figure, the viscosity values are expressed in terms of temperature for different nanofluid samples at a specific shear rate (39.168 S−1). As we can see, with an increase in temperature at a constant volume fraction, the viscosity of the nanofluid decreases. In fact, this behavior can be justified by taking into account the effect of nanoparticle Brownian motion with increasing temperature on the nanofluid viscosity. When the temperature rises, the nanoparticles and base fluid will have a free molecular movement and the nanoparticle molecules collide less. Moreover, with a temperature increase, the intermolecular distance in the nanoparticles and the base fluid is increased, so the resistance to flow, and finally, the viscosity decrease. In other words, viscosity in liquids is due to the adhesive forces of the molecules; so, the viscosity of the liquids decreases with increasing temperature. In liquids, the molecules overcome the intermolecular adhesive forces by more energy at higher
temperatures. As a result, energetic molecules move more freely. For example, as shown in Fig. 5, at the volumetric fraction of 0.2% and temperatures of 35, 40 and 45 ◦C, the nanofluid viscosities are 8.994, 7.598 and 6.886 cP, respectively, indicating that with increasing temperature, the viscosity decreases. Many researchers evaluated the thermophysical properties of nanofluids and showed the similar behavior for them [44–59].

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of volume fraction on nanofluid viscosity
sections.text:
For better understanding the effect of volume fraction on nanofluid viscosity see Fig. 5. In this figure, viscosity values are presented in terms of volume fractions at different temperatures of the nanofluid at a specific shear rate (39.168 S−1). As can be seen, with an increase in the volume fraction, at a constant temperature, the nanofluid viscosity increases. This behavior is due to the fact that one of the influencing factors on the viscosity is the random motions of nanoparticles in the base fluid, which is called the Brownian motion. This random motion is caused by the continuous collision between the nanoparticles and the base fluid molecules. Nanoparticles can be considered bigger in size than the base fluid molecules. Moreover, nanoparticles are moving with an equivalent mean kinetic energy to base fluid molecules.
When the volume fraction increases, the number of nanoparticles present in the base fluid increases. And since viscosity means nanofluid resistance to motion, by adding nanoparticles to the base fluid, we, indeed, increase the resistance to flow. This implies the greater collision of nanoparticles with one another due to the effect of their random motion. Moreover, the viscosity is due to the resistance that produces shear stress against the force applied to the nanofluid. In fact, viscosity is the major reason for the momentum transfer between the nanofluid layers and appears when a movement
occurs between its layers. This movement is due to intermolecular forces. The existence of nanomaterials in the base fluid leads to an increase in the intermolecular forces, which increases the viscosity. In a moving fluid, the layers are in motion at different speeds (fluid has a velocity profile). The fluid viscosity is a result of the shear stress between the layers. By an increase in the number of nanoparticles in the base fluid, the viscose shear stresses inside the nanofluid will increase, leading to an increase in the nanofluid viscosity. If nanomaterials increase in a given volume of base fluid (increase in permeability), gradual increase in shear stress occurs. So, an increase in the number of nanoparticles in the base fluid increases the nanofluid viscosity. Another reason for the increase of the viscosity with volume fraction is the surface-to-volume ratio. Since a very high surface-to-volume ratio is observed in the nanostructures, properties such as density vary due to reduction to nanosize and the importance of floatation and weight forces reduces due to its ultrasmall size and super-low mass, and surface and intermolecular forces become important. Accordingly, if it is assumed that a nanofluid is a two-phase fluid consisting of liquid and solid (assuming, of course), due to the forces incurred, the nanoparticles have the potential to slide on each other and on the base fluid. As a result of sliding, with increasing the volume fraction, the resistance to flow increases and therefore, the viscosity increases. On the other hand, when nanoparticles and nanotubes are added to the base fluid, these nanoparticles are dispersed in the base fluid and form symmetric and larger nanoclusters due to the Van der Waals force between the nanoparticles and the base fluid. These nanoclusters prevent the oil movement, and result in an increased viscosity.
As indicated in Fig. 5, with an increase in the volume fraction of nanoparticles and nanotubes, at a constant temperature, the nanofluid viscosity increases. This increase in volume fraction was expected considering the various
experiments presented by other researchers in this regard. Taking into account Fig. 6, at 35 ◦C, the viscosity of the base fluid is 2.566 cP, which reaches 3.606 cP by adding nanoparticles when the volume fraction is at 0.05 and at the same temperature, and increases to 8.994 and 19.574 cP at the volume fraction of 0.2 and 0.8%, respectively. It can be observed that at a given temperature, the nanofluid viscosity increases by an increase in the volume fraction. The highest increase in the nanofluid viscosity is at the temperature of 25 ◦C and the volume fraction of 0.8%.

sections.heading: 3.4. Power law model
sections.text:
As indicated in Section 3.1, the behavior of the nanoparticles was of the pseudo plastic type and based on the power law model. The relationship between the shear stress and the shear rate in this model is as follows,
τ = mγ̇ n (1)
τ and γ̇ are shear stress and shear rate, respectively. The parameters m and n, known as consistency index and power law index respectively, can be obtained by fitting the shear stress–shear rate curves in Fig. 3. The value of n is variable between zero and one for the pseudo plastic fluids. The smaller the value of n, the higher the pseudo plasticity of the fluid, and where n equals one, the fluid is Newtonian.
As observed in Fig. 3, shear stress is a nonlinear function of the shear rate. It is also understood by analyzing these graphs that the shear stress is also a function of temperature and the volume fraction; therefore, by fitting the curve, the values of m, n and R2 (R2 is the identification coefficient of the index that shows the relationship between the variables and should be close to 1) could be obtained for any temperature and volume fraction. Examples of fitting the power law model curve on experimental data are presented in Fig. 6.
As seen in Fig. 6, there is a good fit here. Moreover, curve fitting was carried out for all nanofluid samples at various temperatures and the results are presented in Fig. 7. Analysis of the index m shows in Fig. 7 that the values of m decrease with an increase in the volume fraction. In fact, the apparent viscosity is directly related to the index m. It is also observed in Fig. 8 that the values of n are always less than 1; i.e. with an increase in the shear rate, the apparent viscosity decreases. Moreover, by increasing the volume fraction, the flow index decreases, meaning that the pseudo plasticity of the fluid is higher.

sections.heading: 3.5. Empirical correlations for the power law model indexes
sections.text:
As we observed, the power law model indexes are a function of the temperature and volume fraction. Therefore, in this section, by using curve fitting, we tried to predict some correlations for the power law indexes.
Eq. (2) shows the function of the curve fit for the prediction the consistency index.
m = (1.42 × 10−8ϕ)(1 +
( (ϕ−0.6313)2
1.191×10−6
)( 1 + ( (T−171.9725)2
14.7101

( ( ϕ(−0.6512) ) ( T 0.4778 ) + (0.4778ϕ) (−0.6512T ) (−0.541ϕ) + (−0.0139T ) + (−6.5932ϕ))
(2)
In this equation, m is the coefficient of fluid strength in Pa.sn, T is the nanofluid temperature in degrees Celsius, and ϕ is the volume fraction in percentage.
Eq. (3) also shows the function of the curve fit for the prediction of the power law index.
n = ( (−0.5436) ϕ(−0.8057)T (−0.0243) ) +
Exp (( −14.3699ϕ2 ) + (0.0675T ) + ( −18.8035ϕ2 ) + ( −0.0005T 2 ))(( ϕ1.0863 ) ( T 0.6229 )) ( T (−0.6226)
) + (ϕ(−0.2628)) (3)
In this equation, n is the behavior of the fluid flow, T is the nanofluid temperature in degrees Celsius, and ϕ is the volume fraction in percentage.
To indicate the accuracy of the proposed equations, Figs. 8 and 9 show comparisons of the values obtained from the proposed correlations with values of m and extracted from experimental results, respectively. As shown in the figures, the fitting of the proposed relations is quite obvious. Therefore, these relations can be relied on for engineering applications.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, the rheological behavior of a mixture of water and ethylene glycol containing hybrid nano-additives of MWCNTs-Al2O3 was investigated experimentally. Homogeneous and stable samples with different solids fractions were prepared by suspending nano-additives in the base fluid. The viscosity of the hybrid nanofluid was measured at different shear rates and temperatures. The accuracy of the measurements was verified by measuring the viscosity of the base fluid and comparing it with the values of ASHRAE handbook. The results showed that the shear stress had a linear relationship with the shear rate at different temperatures for the base fluid, indicating that the base fluid had a Newtonian behavior. The viscosity measurements for different nanofluid samples showed that by adding a small amount of solid nano-material to the base fluid, the rheological behavior changed and the viscosity became a function of the shear rate. It was observed that the viscosity decreased and with increasing temperature and shear rate. In fact, the behavior of the hybrid nanofluid was pseudo-plastic that followed the Power law model. Thus, the values of indexes of power law model were obtained for each temperature and solid volume fraction by fitting the curve on shear stress–shear rate dependency. By evaluation of the behavior of the indexes of power law model, it was found that they are also a function of temperature and volume fraction. Therefore, two-variable correlations were proposed to obtain the consistency index and power law index that have acceptable accuracy.

To avoid mentioned problems, Choi [4] was the first to use the term ‘‘nanofluid’’ for nanoparticles in liquid suspensions, claiming that such fluids are different to conventional solid/liquid suspensions and macro-fluids both in terms of preparation and in terms of stability and transitional characteristics.
Their corrosion is also lower compared to microparticles suspensions [12].

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, the rheological behavior of a mixture of water and ethylene glycol containing a combination of multi-walled carbon nanotubes and aluminum oxide in a temperature range of 25 to 50 C was investigated experimentally. Homogeneous and stable samples with different concentrations were made by suspending carbon nanotubes and aluminum dioxide in a 50–50 mixture of water and ethylene glycol using a two-step method. The viscosity of nanofluid samples at different shear rates was measured by the DV-I PRIME Brookfield digital viscometer, which uses a rotating cylinder method. The results showed that, despite the Newtonian behavior of the base fluid, all nanofluid samples showed a non-Newtonian behavior. It was also observed that non-Newtonian behavior of nanofluid follows the Power law model. Thus, using the curve fitting, the consistency index and the power law index were obtained. Moreover, mathematical correlations were proposed as a function of temperature and volume fraction for obtaining consistency index and the power-law index. Comparisons showed the accuracy of proposed correlations. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
